title: Financial Literacy & Aspirations: Experimental Evidence from Eastern Uganda
image_alt: Women participating in a financial literacy session
image_caption: Community sessions paired with a mobile game and an aspirations film.
standfirst: Mobile-based financial education and an aspirations documentary aimed at boosting women’s money skills and future planning.
summary: This project focused on improving women’s financial literacy and aspirations through mobile games and an aspirations video. Early evidence indicates meaningful gains in basic financial knowledge and empowerment.
highlights: Offline-first mobile game covering budgeting, saving, and goal setting
Aspirations short film with relatable local role models
Simple facilitator guides with pre/post micro-quizzes

sections.title: Background & Objectives
sections.html: Women in low-connectivity contexts face limited access to actionable, engaging financial education. The project objective is to provide short, practical learning that fits community schedules and strengthens agency through aspiration-building stories.

sections.title: Intervention Design
sections.html:
• Lightweight Android game with short scenarios (budgeting, savings discipline, coping with shocks).
  • Aspirations short film featuring local entrepreneurs and goal-setting routines.
  • Micro-quizzes for before/after comparisons and discussion prompts.

sections.title: Implementation
sections.html: Delivered via existing women’s groups with community champions. Sessions run 60–90 minutes, combining group viewing, gameplay, and reflection. Paper back-ups ensure inclusivity for participants without phones.

sections.title: Early Learning
sections.html:
• High engagement with story-driven content; participants referenced film characters during discussions.
  • Micro-quiz results show improved understanding of basic budgeting and savings goals.
  • Requests for refresher sessions and spouse/partner inclusion.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.html: Refine modules (household budgeting, savings groups, micro-enterprise planning), expand to new districts, and explore light-touch follow-ups by SMS/WhatsApp where available.

title: Green Riches, Golden Assets: Uganda’s Dietary Patterns
image_alt: Satellite map layers of vegetation across Uganda
image_caption: NDVI greenness layers matched to household areas and asset indices.
standfirst: Geospatial greenery (NDVI), household assets, and dietary diversity—how environment and socio-economics intersect.
summary: Using geospatial tools, this project examined the relationship between environmental greenness, household assets, and diet diversity in Uganda. Results highlight the conditioning role of socio-economic status and market access.
highlights: NDVI and land-cover layers processed in Google Earth Engine
Household asset indices built from inventories
Dietary diversity constructed from food group coverage

sections.title: Concept & Questions
sections.html: We ask whether greener environments predict more diverse diets and how this relationship is shaped by wealth, access to markets, and seasonality.

sections.title: Data & Measures
sections.html:
• Environment: NDVI and land-cover rasters; administrative boundaries for aggregation.
  • Assets: Household inventory-based indices.
  • Diet diversity: Food groups consumed over a reference period.

sections.title: Findings
sections.html:
• Greenness correlates with diet diversity, but effects attenuate for lower-asset households.
  • Market proximity and seasonality mediate the environment–diet link.
  • Policy implication: combine livelihoods, market linkage, and behavior change—not greenery alone.

sections.title: Limitations & Next Steps
sections.html: Spatial resolution and household geolocation uncertainty may bias estimates. Next steps include adding market price time-series and diet cost indices.

title: Entrepreneurship Education in Uganda
image_caption: Applied workshops co-designed with local businesses.
standfirst: Co-designed, modular training and mentorship that fits around trading hours and real SME constraints.
summary: A collaboration between academia and local businesses to develop tailored educational content for entrepreneurs. Hundreds have received practical training and mentorship through workshops and follow-up clinics.
highlights: Short, modular lessons: pricing, cashflow, customer retention
Mentorship circles pairing founders with experienced operators
Simple templates: cashflow sheet, pricing calculator, customer log

sections.title: Why This Program
sections.html: Many entrepreneurs lack compact, context-fit training that translates into day-to-day operational changes. We designed modules that fit trading hours and emphasize immediate practice.

sections.title: Program Components
sections.html:
• Interactive, 60–90 minute modules with local caselets.
  • Mentorship circles and peer accountability.
  • Templates for cashflow, costing, and customer tracking.

sections.title: Learning & Adaptation
sections.html: Participants report better costing and record-keeping, with demand for refresher clinics. Future cohorts will include inventory and supplier management.

title: Bootcamps — Street-Smart Entrepreneurship & Case Writing
image_caption: Hands-on bootcamps that produce usable outputs in days.
standfirst: Short, intensive and practical bootcamps that help entrepreneurs improve their businesses and help faculty produce classroom-ready Business Teaching Case Studies (BTCS).
summary: Two complementary bootcamp tracks—Entrepreneur Bootcamp and Case-Writing Sprint—deliver tangible outputs fast (cashbooks, pricing sheets, sales scripts, and draft teaching cases). The design is local, ethical, and low-bandwidth, with simple follow-up clinics for sustained outcomes.
highlights: Real businesses, real numbers, practical tools

sections.title: What is a Bootcamp?
sections.html: A short, intensive, hands-on program that compresses learning and production into a few days. Participants leave with tangible outputs they can use immediately.

sections.title: Design Principles
sections.html:
• Local & practical: use real businesses and plain language.
  • Evidence-based: simple worksheets and data logs to support decisions.
  • Low-bandwidth: works offline with paper/Excel backups.
  • Ethical & fair: informed consent, anonymisation options, and share-back value.

sections.title: Formats
sections.html:
5-Day Case-Writing Sprint (Faculty/Researchers)

  1. Case method basics, consent & ethics; outline a case.
  2. Field protocols and interviews/observation.
  3. Analysis: profitability, efficiency, diversification, HR, survival strategies.
  4. Draft case + instructor note; peer review.
  5. Micro-teaching/pilot and revision plan.

3-Day Entrepreneur Bootcamp

  1. Map customers/channels; set up a cashbook.
  2. Pricing & unit economics; customer discovery scripts; simple sales plan.
  3. Operations & HR basics; micro-pitch; 30-day targets.

Joint Model

Pair faculty teams with entrepreneurs. Mornings = skills; afternoons = fieldwork; evenings = peer review. Outcome: a usable case draft and a stronger business.

sections.title: Tools (Offline / Low-Cost)
sections.html:
• Data collection: ODK/Kobo or paper forms.
  • Writing: Google Docs offline or LibreOffice; export to PDF.
  • Finance: Excel cashbook, pricing & breakeven sheets.
  • Storage: numbered consent forms and a simple data dictionary.

sections.title: Ethics & IP
sections.html:
• Written informed consent with option to anonymise names/figures.
  • Share-back: a one-pager for the business (tips + simple metrics).
  • Clear use rights for teaching/publishing BTCS.

sections.title: Success Metrics
sections.html:
• 60–80% of cases reach publishable draft within 4–6 weeks.
  • ≥70% of entrepreneurs maintain a cashbook after 30 days.
  • Concrete improvements: price changes, cost trims, better customer scripts.

sections.title: Timeline
sections.html:
1. Week 0: recruit & consent.
  2. Week 1: bootcamp delivery (3–5 days).
  3. Weeks 2–3: drafting and edits.
  4. Week 4: micro-teaching/pilot.
  5. Weeks 6–8: finalisation and upload; clinic #1.
  6. Month 3: clinic #2 and outcome check.

sections.title: Budget (Indicative)
sections.html: Venue/meals, local transport, printing, small stipends, and facilitation typically total USD 3–7k per cohort (size-dependent). Add USD 1–2k for follow-up clinics and editing to reach classroom-ready cases.

sections.title: Risks & Mitigation
sections.html:
• Time slippage: daily checkpoints and end-of-day deliverables.
  • Data gaps: capture ranges/ratios when exact figures are sensitive.
  • Drop-off: schedule two clinics in advance and create a peer group (WhatsApp/Signal).

sections.title: Expected Outputs
sections.html:
• 6–10 draft teaching cases with instructor notes.
  • Cashbooks, pricing sheets, and sales scripts for participating businesses.
  • A short evidence brief on street-smart models for partners and policy.
  • A sustained community of practice for continued peer feedback.
